block.p: 1. The research has not explained how the image on the linen, from the Shroud of Turin, was created.

2. Many Arab countries had banned the works of Naguib Mahfouz, an Egyptian who is the first Arabic Nobel Laureate in Literature, because of his support of President Anwar el-Sadat's treaty with Israel.
3. Nine arrests resulted from invitations that were sent out by Customs Service agents to people suspected of money laundering after a two-year undercover operation.
4. Mr. Gorbachev proposed that lands from the huge state farms and collective farms be privately leased to families or groups of farmers.
5. With its victory over Princeton, Columbia ended its 44-game losing streak.
6. China offered to provide a refuge for Pol Pot and other leaders of the Khmer Rouge, whose exile is considered a key part of any setttlement of the war.

7. The Savannah River Plant, whose nuclear reactors were shut in August for safety reasons, is the nation's only manufacturer of tritium, and the United States might thus be forced to start deactivating some nuclear warheads to recover tritium for use in weapons with a higher priority.
8. Jay Howell of the Dodgers was ejected from the third game of the National League playoffs after handing the umpire a glove he had rubbed with pine tar.
9. Acquiring the shuttle may improve the present poor air service to Atlantic City, where Mr. Trump owns two hotel-casinos.

10. Legislators have been reluctant to shut military bases in their districts, and the bill gives a Pentagon-appointed commission the responsibility for making the decisions about which obsolete bases should be closed.

11. The fires are set by townspeople to push back the jungle and increase the land's value for cattle grazing. Environmentalists worry over vast emissions of carbon dioxide contributing to potentially dangerous warming of the earth.

12. Some think the Republicans have a ''lock'' on the Electoral College, which chooses the President, because in the last five elections 23 states with a total of 202 electoral votes (out of the 270 needed to win) have voted Republican.
13. Researchers conclude that migraine headaches are not psychosomatic but a biological disease of the central nervous system.
14. The city is in danger of borrowing more than it can afford to repay for projects to repair its deteriorating public works.

15. It was the first time mathematicians had split a number 100 digits long into two large prime factors. Since several of the most secure cipher systems are based on the high improbability of that feat, the accomplishment may force cryptographers to reassess the security and future of some codes used by governments and banks.
